comments.commentBody:
The Times sure makes it sound so innocent in the headlines but the truth is Obama and some in his administration knew early on this company was destined to fail but they approved giving the owners $500 million of our dollars and oddly enough the Company's Execs donated a bunch of money to Obama. It's a good gig if you can get it. Hey Mr. President if you give me $500 million in tax money for my bankrupt company, I'll give you back half of that for your campaign. Good deal.

All of these bozos on the Brooklyn Bridge need to be looking at Obama and the Government instead of Wall Street. See if we don't like Wall Street or Bankers we don't have to invest, we can keep our earnings under our mattresses if we want. But if we get mad at the Government, too bad, we're stuck with them and we can't do a thing. Banks aren't stealing our money and giving it to someone else. The Government is pointing a gun to our heads and robbing us blind and we can't do a darn thing. You protestors are nothing but Obama lackeys, getting used by the democrats and loving it.
Is there any doubt that your president is a Train Wreck? Get rid of him. Even if that means voting for Perry!

It's amusing reading the "outrage" of the Obama haters, right-wing extremists, Tea Partiers, Republicans, and the like, all up in arms over an investment that went bad, for one company.

If this were a Republican administration, I suspect we wouldn't hear a peep from these same vociferous, unhinged critics. But of course, a Republican administration wouldn't "waste" a mere $500 million trying to develop, a clean, renewable, energy alternative. They would have spent at least ten times that amount in subsidies, tax cuts and other special favors for their friends and cronies in Big Energy, who are already fantastically wealthy with a virtual monopoly in the toxic world of nuclear power and fossil fuels.

Where were these people when the Bush Administration was handing out billions---yes billions!---in no bid contracts to companies ranging from Blackwater to Hailiburton?

Where were these people when several of those contractors couldn't even account for several billion? Have those dollars EVER been accounted for?

Where are those people right now, as we're still spending $500 million PER DAY, occupying Iraq and Afghanistan, essentially to secure "our oil"?

And, why aren't these people acknowledging that the overwhelming majority of these alternative energy investments worked out just fine? Out of 11 of these loans, only ONE went bad. Why isn't the media making that clear?

Finally, the only reason these right-wingers can troll on here, and pontificate, and viciously attack the future---yes, like it or not, people, Alternative Energy is BOTH our economic and energy future!---is because of a massive government investment called The Internet. (Or, as George W. Bush put it, "The Internets")

Other countries will overrun us and ultimately crush us if we allow the enemies of progress to attack "government loans". Countries, including China, are investing heavily in this and other technologies and they'll end up "eating our lunch" as remain stuck in the past.
What about $Trillion wasted in Iraq and $Billion fraudulently taken away , no congressional investigation and no blames.

The Department of Energy is to Solyndra what the State Department is to the TransCanada pipeline--fronting for a corporation whose business model is lobby, lobby, lobby, and sweep under the rug all questionable aspects.  I hope both decisions (State is playing coy about granting final approval, but what it has already said removes any possible objections) come back to haunt the Obama administration because of its flagrant favoritism shown business.  Obama has turned regulation on its head.  Even Presidents Coolidge and Hoover would have been embarrassed by such gross imbalance in public policy.

Everything that every administration does is political, so surely there were political considerations in giving this particular company the loan/grant. Even if there was no improper company use of the funds, the decision to build a huge factory was probably influenced by the administration's huge influx of risk-free capital. All sorts of bad decisions are made when spending other people's money. Bad ideas suddenly seem like good ideas. A venture capitalist would be more likely to calculate the probability of return on investment- the government is spending the taxpayers' money and doesn't care.

I live in a very liberal midwestern city in a state that has required voters to display their driver's license or other vaild ID for several years now.  Their was no whining here when the new law went into effect.  Voting is a privilege meant for citizens of the United States.  And yes, there is voter fraud, much more than this article would have one believe.  We don't allow citizen felons to vote, people who have paid their debt.  (I think they should be allowed to vote.)  Yet we should allow a non-citizen to vote? And a young person will be intimidated by showing his or her license?  Come on now.  With that logic young people would not have to show their ID in a bar becsuse they woulld simply die of fright.  You're trying to create a tempest in a teapot.

This move is so incredibly political and nothing else it's sickening.  The Bush Justice Dept. did a multi-year study all over the country on so-called voter fraud.  With all of the resources at its beck and call, it found exactly 32 cases country-wide and was able to successfully prosecute just 13.  Here we have people yapping about needless spending and for overt political reasons willing to spend on a totally needless program.  How can anyone come to any other conclusion than willfully blatant disenfranchisement?
The biggest fraud is with the Republican Party.

It is so disheartening to read this and know that apparently there are millions of regular Americans who still believe that these people have their interests at heart. This bill reads like a page from a manifesto for the creation a conservative dystopia. It's just incredible to me that Republicans can pursue these kind of policies and still succeed in making people believe that they are anything more than power-drunk hypocrites whose perverse sense of superiority allows them to justify anything, including ruining the future for their own grandchildren.

Here's the crazy thing - the voters supporting this radical political agenda are the exact same voters who will be most hurt by the cuts. The Republicans have such a sweet thing going. Talk anti-abortion and "Christian values" and the sheep will follow them straight off the cliff.

N of NYC has it right.A cause without a leader is worthless.a purpose without vision has a weak following. Laws in a democracy can only] be modified by a legislature elected by the people.
Progressive action in the street is meaningless and short of the demise of government , the ballot box is the only answer. The "Establishment" has the dogs ,firehoses and batons.

We marched against the War and marched in the South and we still haven't seen "The Mountain Top"
You didn't like my stage directions?

Also.
I know of a witness in a high profile rape case who was escorted out of her apartment and to the waiting police car with a blanket over her so no one would know who she was.
If they went through all that then it would only stand to reason that a witness to a crime wouldn't be walked up the front stairs, and paraded down the aisle of the court room.
So, this entrance/exit has been used before but, just not for the Mayor of New York.
bloomberg's handlers didn't want it to look like a prep walk which basically it was.

My personal favorites:

1. The mother who changed her toddler's diaper in a fountain in the garden area of a restaurant, in full view of at least 30 patrons, in Park Slope (of course). We left after drinks.

2. The parents who responded when their baby began banging spoons on the table by pounding the table with their hands in a similar rhythm (Park Slope again). The next Mozart, no doubt.

3. The parents and grandparents who allowed a toddler to play a child's computer game, complete with maddening, repetitive children's music, over and over again, while laughingly announcing to the wait staff that they had no idea how to turn down the sound or shut the thing off, even though they knew it was driving the other customers crazy.

Here's what we've learned. Stay away from places with menus for children. Don't go to dinner before 8 p.m. Look at the clientele -- white, American, upper middle class children are the most out of control, while Hispanic, Asian, and African-American parents, parents from other countries, and working-class parents of all races actually exert some authority over their children because they are less likely to think that their kids are "special."

Above all, don't go out to dinner in Park Slope.
Welcome to Park Slope.

I appreciated the comments written about some recent experiences related to noisy, mis-behaved children at restaurants. I used to share this view and have friends that also are annoyed at the noise created by loud shrieks and related disturbance. But, one day my opinions were altered, like after I became a parent and have the responsibility of raising a child to behave appropriately.

The concepts of an "inside" vs. "outside" voice are great, but when you have a toddler that has yet to develop an understanding of voice, what is a parent to do. As a parent , my wife and I scope out restaurants(on the rare occasion we can go out) that are kid/family friendly. Recently, we passed up a location with a menu screaming fabulous to go to a pizza restaurant, as the first location was a bit quiet for the potential of our toddler. We continue to coach and work on the occasional screech!!!!!!!!, yikes, as a 16 month old child is in the process of learning their limits. Sometimes my child seems to be reaching for the upper limits of the octive that shatters the crystal. Prior to having children and complaining to a parent was most tactfully answered with, do you have kids? If you don't or have not had the privilege or raising your own children or grand kids, than you need to grow up as well. Learn to be a bit more tolerant and appreciate the life children bring to everyone around. And when the bread hits you off the back of your head and the ear drums have developed a numbing sensation after successive screeches, please take a deep breath and smile at the challenges facing parents. As a smile can be the most disarming action, save for the ear plugs/sock stuffed in the mouth. As a parent, I will continue to work with my little one and of those around me, but would like to patronize local "family" friendly restaurants when possible. Hopefully, other parents will do the same...

Best,

Rob H.
Manhatten

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody: The Yanks are behaving like Boston.

Is Giradi out of his mind ? Why didn't he use Robertson instead of Soriano ?
This is such an important and pivotal game not using his best reliever.

This looks like a real movement, yet the media are giving it short shrift. When the tea party, a fake movement by far, began, the media covered their every incoherent word. Just goes to show how media are controlled by corporations.
Excellent! Now where can we read the OWSJ online?
How can I subscribe to the Occupied Wall Street Journal?

Girardi inexplicably goes to Ayala in gm 2, leaves CC in too long and let's Soriano pitch multiple innings!! Why, Joe?? You gotta handle starting pitchers and pen like there's no tomorrow (which there might be soon!) not like you're managing in August!!
How ironic that it should come down to AJ. If it's the good AJ, we have a chance (with some timely hitting). If it's the bad AJ, we're dead.
